description: Borrowed from Latin fulcrum (“bedpost, foot of a couch”), from fulciō (“prop up, support”).

entries.meaning: (mechanics) The support about which a lever pivots.
examples: It is possible to flick food across the table using your fork as a lever and your finger as a fulcrum.

entries.meaning: (figurative) A crux or pivot; a central point.
examples: By this point the fulcrum of concern is the stuprum of men upon men, described as more prevalent than that upon women.
